item.title: Road to BurntToast v1: Actionable Toast for All!
item.description: BurntToast is finally growing up. It’s going through puberty and will see a v1 release when it gets to the other side… but it’ll be a journey.

item.title: Crouton #15 - You Can't Silence Toast
item.description: Focus assist is a favoured tool of practiced speakers and presenters on Windows. It does put you in a bit of a bind if the thing you’re presenting requires notifications though.

item.title: Actionable Toast Notifications, Finally Cracked Them!
item.description: I don’t know how to express a happy dance with text. If I could that’s what would be here because I’ve finally removed a thorn from my side that’s been there for five years.

item.title: The Anatomy of Toast
item.description: BurntToast just turned five, and I’ve only now realized that I’ve never written about how all the module’s “advanced” functions work together to create a toast notification.

item.title: Crouton #14 - Fancy Buttons
item.description: It’s all well and good putting buttons all over your toast notification, but text is a little plain. Let’s see how we can dress out buttons up a little bit!

item.title: Crouton #13 - Hitting Snooze
item.description: Hitting snooze on your alarm clock is probably rather common. Let’s take a look at how you can do the same thing with your Toast Notifications.

item.title: Crouton #12 - Toasting in Many Tongues (Tōhi o nga reo maha)
item.description: Toast notification data bindings have a number of uses. We’ve already covered updating toasts, now let’s teach our notifications a second language.

item.title: Crouton #11 - Updating Toast Notifications, Gracefully
item.description: Following the release of BurntToast v0.7.0 there were a couple of headline features that needed to be written about. Shoulder Taps had their time in the spotlight and now it’s the turn of Updatable Toasts.

item.title: Crouton #10 - Cold Shoulder (Taps)
item.description: If you can forgive incomplete help, the latest update of BurntToast has some cool new features. First one we’ll be covering is Shoulder Taps!

item.title: Everything Is Better with Toast: Getting Build Notifications
item.description: When you want to keep an eye on build results, but don’t want to dedicate a screen to the web page, toast is the answer!

item.title: Crouton #8 Redux - Now with a More Complete Example
item.description: I didn’t do the best job of the examples in my original post on this topic. Let’s put that right.

item.title: Crouton #9 - Free, with Attribution
item.description: Where did that toast come from? Who cooked it?! If only it was attributed to someone…

item.title: Crouton #8 - I like Your Code, but I Don't Want It on All My Computers
item.description: I get you; you like toast, but you don’t want to put a toaster on 100 desks.

item.title: Downloading an Image for Local Use
item.description: This has been sitting as an open issue on the project for a long time and given how quick of a fix it was I’m disappointed that I didn’t get to it sooner.

item.title: Crouton #7 – Superhero Landing
item.description: Ever find yourself needing to get an image up on your screen in a timely manner?

item.title: Crouton #6 – Dance to Your Own Beat
item.description: It gives me a glimpse into how people are using the module and it also focuses my documentation efforts on something that might actually be useful.

item.title: Need PowerShell Help? Use #PSHelp!
item.description: If you’re looking for some help, try #PSHelp. If you’ve got knowledge to share (and you do), make sure you jump in and get involved!

item.title: DIY AppId and WiX, for Tasty Toast
item.description: This time around, I’ll walk you through how to create your own installer.

item.title: BurntToast + AppId = It's Working!
item.description: I can’t tell you how happy I am to be writing this post.

item.description: How the heck did that happen, isn’t the system meant to give me some warning?

item.title: BurntToast Breaking Change: Hiding Customizable AppID
item.description: I hate reducing customizability, just as much as I hate making breaking changes in my projects.

item.title: Crouton #4 – Getting Your Head Around Headers
item.description: Headers, introduced in the Creators Update, can be used to organize you toasts.

item.title: Crouton #3 - Sometimes You Just Want to Click Your Toast
item.description: Buttons can look pretty ugly when only using one, so just click your Toast instead!

item.description: April saw the release of the Creators Update for Windows 10 which brought with it a handful of new options for toast notifications.
